title: 107_hr383
content: Section 1 introduces a new section in the Internal Revenue Code, titled "Health Insurance and Prescription Drug Costs," which amends Part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 by redesignating section 222 as section 223. The deduction for medical care expenses includes insurance premiums and unreimbursed prescription drug costs for the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. Employer contributions to certain accounts are treated as paid by the employer. The deduction for ancillary coverage premiums such as accidents, disability, dental care, vision care, or hospitalization payments is not available under subsection (a). The amount considered for the deduction under section 162(l) does not apply to this section or the medical expense deduction. The taxpayer's deduction under this section does not include the amount considered for the deduction under section 213. Definitions for "medical care" and exclusion of certain insurance contracts are provided. The term 'unreimbursed prescription drug expenses' refers to costs for prescribed drugs not reimbursed by insurance. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary. The deduction for health insurance and prescription drug costs is allowed whether or not the taxpayer itemizes other deductions. Clerical amendments are made to the table of sections. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. Deduction for 100 percent of health insurance and prescription drug costs of self-employed individuals. The amendment allows self-employed individuals to deduct 100 percent of health insurance costs and unreimbursed prescription drug expenses for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The amendment clarifies limitations on coverage for subsidized health plans and prescription drug expenses for self-employed individuals, their spouse, and dependents. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2002.
